article.description:
With the most important part of the
season still to come, senior guard Brandin Knight of No. 8
Pittsburgh seems ready to shine.
article.headline: Knight makes six 3-pointers in defeat of Hokies
article.linkText: Knight, Pittsburgh too much for Virginia Tech
article.story: BLACKSBURG, Va. (AP) -- With the most important part of the season still to come, senior guard Brandin Knight of No. 8 Pittsburgh seems ready to shine. Knight scored 25 points and hit two of his six 3-pointers during a run that thwarted Virginia Tech's last comeback try Wednesday night in the Panthers' 75-62 victory. "That's what you want,'' Pittsburgh coach Ben Howland said. "A senior on the road leading you to a victory. They played a lot of zone and I thought we attacked their zone well.'' The victory gave the Panthers (20-4, 10-3 Big East) consecutive 20-win seasons for the first time since 1987-88, and sent the Hokies to their fifth consecutive loss. Knight had a lot to do with it, hitting six of eight 3-point shots to tie a career high, making 7-of-10 from the field overall and adding four assists and just one turnover. The biggest shot of all came after the Hokies pulled to 58-50 and seemed poised to make a run at the Panthers after trailing by double figures for most of the game. Knight hit his fifth 3-pointer with 5:37 left and added another with 3:52 to play, capping a 9-2 run that gave the Panthers a 67-52 lead and allowed them to coast the rest of the way. The Panthers shot 53 percent and made 11 3-pointers in 25 tries, foiling the Hokies' attempt at using a zone defense to shut off the middle and force the Panthers outside. "Our game plan was to force them to make shots from the perimeter,'' Virginia Tech coach Ricky Stokes said. "And they did.'' Virginia Tech (10-16, 3-10) fell into a tie with Miami for last place in the Big East's East Division, with a game against the Hurricanes in Blacksburg a week away. "You just have to go out there and do it,'' said Hokies forward Bryant Matthews, who scored 17 points. "We'll be back to square one tomorrow at practice.'' The Panthers essentially took control early, scoring seven straight points to take a 27-17 lead 5:33 before halftime and allowing the lead to get into single digits only five times. Each time, they responded immediately with points. "They're a patient and methodical team; they (don't) get rattled,'' Stokes said. "They made some key plays down the stretch to not let us get back in the game.'' The victory allowed the Panthers to keep pace with Syracuse atop the Big East West. The 15th-ranked Orangemen beat West Virginia 89-51. Jaron Brown and Julius Page each added 11 points for the Panthers. Terry Taylor also scored 17 for the Hokies, who started a critical three-game homestand. Virginia Tech is trying to qualify for the Big East tournament for the first time in three years. To do it, they have to avoid finishing last in their division.
